Detailed Visa Guides

Everything you need to know about each visa type

Digital Nomad Visa
Complete application guide
6-10 weeks$100-150
Duration
180 days (6 months)
Work Allowed
Remote work for foreign companies only
Residency Path
No direct path
Who This Visa Is Actually For
Software developers working remotely
perfect fit
Freelance designers/writers
perfect fit
Digital marketers
good fit
Online teachers
good fit
People wanting to work for Argentine companies
not-suitable fit
Requirements Checklist
  • Valid passport with 6+ months validity
  • Proof of remote work (employment contract or client agreements)
  • Minimum income proof (~$2,500/month recommended)
  • Health insurance valid in Argentina
  • Criminal background check (apostilled)
  • Proof of accommodation in Argentina
Common Rejection Reasons
Insufficient income proof
Solution: Provide 6 months of bank statements showing consistent income
Background check issues
Solution: Ensure your background check is apostilled and less than 90 days old
Incomplete documentation
Solution: Double-check all required documents before submitting
Previous visa overstays
Solution: If you overstayed before, consult a lawyer first
Step-by-Step Application Process
1

Gather documents

2-4 weeks

Get background check, translate documents, secure accommodation proof

2

Create RADEX account

Same day

Register on the Migraciones online system

3

Submit application

1-2 hours

Upload all documents and pay fee online

4

Wait for review

4-8 weeks

Migraciones reviews your application

5

Receive approval

1 week

Download your visa approval letter

6

Enter Argentina

Within 90 days

You have 90 days to enter after approval

Cost Breakdown

Official Government Fees

  • Visa application fee$100-150
  • Entry fee (reciprocity)$0-160 (varies by nationality)

Additional/Hidden Costs

  • Document apostille$50-150
  • Certified translations$100-300
  • Health insurance$50-200/month
  • Photos and copies$20-50
  • Transport to Migraciones$10-30
Real Stories from Successful Applicants
Marcus, 34, Developer

Got approved in 7 weeks. Key was having 6 months of consistent freelance income documented. The background check took longest - start that first.

Tip: Use the RADEX system, not in-person. Much faster.
Sofia, 29, Designer

Rejected first time due to 'insufficient ties to home country.' Added a letter from my landlord and utility bills, then approved in 5 weeks.

Tip: Show you have a life to return to - leases, subscriptions, etc.

Practical Information

What you need to know about the actual application process

Insider Tips from Successful Applicants

Timing Is Everything
  • Apply at least 3 months before your planned move
  • Avoid December-February (summer holidays - everything slows down)
  • Start your background check first - it takes the longest
  • Document validity: Most documents expire after 90 days
Documentation Secrets
  • Scan everything in high resolution (300 DPI minimum)
  • Keep PDFs under 5MB for RADEX uploads
  • Make a checklist and check it three times
  • Apostille rules vary by US state - check yours
Money Matters
  • Bring more money than the minimum requirement
  • Have 6 months of bank statements ready
  • Credit cards help show financial stability
  • Budget for the unexpected - costs add up
Getting Help
  • Facebook groups: Argentine Expats and Expats in Buenos Aires
  • Reddit: r/argentina and r/expats
  • Consider a lawyer for complex cases (worth the $500-1500)
  • Your embassy can't help with immigration, but expat groups can

Important Legal Notice

Visa requirements, fees, and processing times change frequently. This guide reflects information current as of 2025 but should not be considered legal advice. Always verify current requirements on the official Argentine Immigration website or consult with a qualified immigration attorney before making decisions. We are not responsible for changes in immigration law or individual application outcomes.

Need Professional Help?

Immigration law is complex and changes frequently. A qualified lawyer can save you time, money, and stress - especially for business visas or if you've had previous immigration issues.
